intro: Dinochloa tjankorreh var. angustifolia, commonly known as the narrow-leafed dinochloa, is a rare and specialized plant species native to specific regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, grass-like morphology. The plant exhibits a low-growing habit with narrow, linear leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. It thrives in arid or semi-arid environments, typically in rocky or sandy soils, and is adapted to withstand extreme temperature fluctuations. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
